title: U.S. stocks pull back after strongest rally in a month; Earnings misses from Snap, Twitter helped weigh on the Nasdaq
text:
* The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA gained 156 points, or 0.5%, to 32,189.

* The S&P 500 SPX gained 3 points, or 0.1%, to 4,002.

* The Nasdaq Composite COMP shed 43 points, or 0.4%, to 12,012.

On Thursday, the Dow climbed 162.06 points, or 0.5%, to 32,036.90, the S&P 500 gained 1% to 3,998.95 and the Nasdaq rose 1.4% to 12,059.61, marking a third straight session of gains.

Need to Know: UBS isn't yet a believer in the rally. Here's its advice on what to do now.

What's driving markets?

After the S&P 500 index briefly broke above 4,000 for the first time since June 9, stocks turned lower following the release of the latest flash reading of the S&P Global's Composite Purchasing Managers' Index, a leading indicator of economic activity for the services and manufacturing sectors. A blended gauge showed the biggest contraction in at least two years.

See: U.S. July flash PMI data show 'worrying deterioration' in economy

"The preliminary PMI data for July point to a worrying deterioration in the economy," Chris Williamson, chief business economist at S&P Global Market Intelligence said. "Excluding pandemic lockdown months, output is falling at a rate not seen since 2009."

But from a purely technical perspective, stocks were likely due for a pullback on Friday, said Kevin Dempter, a technical analyst at Renaissance Macro.

"You've had a 10% rally off the lows for the S&P, and a 15% for the Nasdaq. You're getting to overbought levels, and you're hitting some levels of resistance," Dempter said.

On the earnings front, disappointing results from Snapchat parent Snap Inc. SNAP and Twitter Inc. TWTR weighed on the Nasdaq, while an encouraging report from American Express AXPhelped support the Dow.

Opinion: As Snap melts down, its founders make sure to protect the people who matter: themselves

"The Snap results came as a warning for other Big Tech names that rely on ad revenue," said Ipek Ozkardeskaya, senior analyst at Swissquote, in a note to clients.

Next week will see some of the biggest tech names on Wall Street report, including Microsoft MSFT, Meta, Apple AAPL and Amazon AMZN, along with Boeing BA, McDonald's MCD and Caterpillar CAT.

The 10-year Treasury yield BX:TMUBMUSD10Y fell 11 basis points to 2.799% from 2.908% in the previous session as investor worries over a possible U.S. recession lingered.

The euro EURUSD was weaker against the dollar on Friday, trading down 0.6% at $1.0167, one day after the European Central Bank hiked interest rates for the first time in 11 years, following PMI data that showed a contraction in the eurozone. The German 10-year bund yield BX:TMBMKDE-10Y tumbled 19 basis points to 1.03%. Still, the shared currency has risen nearly 1% against the dollar this week, and is on track to snap a three-week losing streak, according to Dow Jones Market Data.

What companies are in focus?

* Verizon Communications Inc. stock VZ tumbled 2.7% after the telecommunications groupcut full-year guidance and missedsecond-quarter earnings and revenue estimates.

* Schlumberger Ltd. SLB shares rose after the oilfield equipment and services group reported better-than-expected resultsand lifted its outlook.

* Seagate Technology Holdings PLC STX were down more than 10% after the data-storage device group's results and outlook fell short of Wall Street expectations.

* Mattel Inc. MAT fell 2.5% after the toymaker reported a forecast-beating quarterly profit, but a 20% slump in sales of its American Girl business.

* HCA Healthcare Inc. HCAwas the best performer on the S&P 500, rising more than 14% after a strong earnings report.

How are other assets trading?

* Oil futures were lower, with U.S. crude CL.1 CLU22 falling 75 cents, or 0.8%, to $95.59 a barrel, after slumping 3.5% on Thursday. Brent crude BRN00 BRNU22 , the global benchmark, fell $1.17, or 1.1%, to $102.76 a barrel, a day after sliding 2.9% to its lowest since July 15 of $103.86 a barrel.

* Gold GC00 GCQ22 rose $13.80, or 0.8%, to $1.727.10 an ounce.

* Bitcoin BTCUSD was higher at $23,639.

* The Stoxx Europe 600 index XX:SXXP rose 0.4%.

U.S. stocks pull back after strongest rally in a month
